questions.question: Question 1: Which electrophysiological activity is responsible for the T wave in ECG?
questions.explanation: The T wave in ECG is due to ventricular repolarisation.

questions.question:
Question 2: The PR intervals obtained from the ECG recording of 4 patients are given below. Which of the 
following patients has a normal PR interval?
questions.explanation:
The normal duration of the PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds (3 to 5 small boxes). PR interval is said to be prolonged if it is > 0.2 seconds and short if it is < 0.12 seconds. It is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It 
represents the time from the start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization. 813 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: What is the normal QRS interval?
questions.explanation:
The normal duration of the QRS interval is normally 0.1-0.11 seconds (less than 3 small boxes). QRS interval represents the duration of ventricular depolarization. When the QRS complex is > 
0.11 seconds, it is called a wide QRS complex. It can occur in: • Bundle branch blocks (RBBB or LBBB) • Depolarizations originating in the ventricles • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome • Hyperkalaemia

questions.question:
Question 4: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG? 803 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the 
depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus. Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a 
positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead 
produces a negative deflection in the ECG. The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart. 814 
Sold by @itachibot The given image shows a normal 12 lead ECG:

questions.question:
Question 5: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the 
following lead(s)?
questions.explanation:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only. Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 
consists of: • Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector) • Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector) 815 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following leads would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +‹0 
degrees?
questions.explanation:
With the cardiac axis at +‹0 degrees, lead aVF would show the maximum R wave. The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector). The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between 
-30 degrees and +100 degrees. The position of lead aVF is at +‹0 degrees. If the cardiac axis is also at +‹0 degrees, it would be in 
the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude. If the mean axis is: • More negative than –30 degrees: left axis deviation • More positive than +‹0 to +100 degrees: right axis deviation • Lies between -‹0 to +1˜0 degrees: extreme axis deviation 816 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality?
questions.explanation: Pseudo P pulmonale refers to tall peaked P waves seen in hypokalemia. P-pulmonale refers to P waves taller than >2.5mm in an ECG lead. Hypocalcemia (Option C) prolongs the QT interval. Hypercalcemia (Option D) shortens the QT interval.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following ECG findings are seen in a patient with hypokalemia?

options.a: Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation
options.b: Decreased PR interval with ST depression
options.c: Decreased QT interval with tall T waves
options.d: Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves

questions.explanation:
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves is seen in hypokalemia. 817 
Sold by @itachibot Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization. The ECG changes seen are as follows: • Flattening of T wave • ST-segment depression • Prolongation of QT interval • The appearance of U wave

questions.question:
Question 9: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to 
the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
questions.explanation:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen 
in left atrial enlargement. This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to 
his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis 
lead to left atrial dilation. The features of P mitrale are: • lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves • Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed 
depolarization of the LA) P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. 818 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below 
shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead 
V6. Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below). 819 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD presented with worsening dyspnea for 2 weeks. On 
examination, pedal edema was present. An ECG was done and lead II showed the following 
pattern. Which of the following is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.explanation:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called P pulmonale and it is seen in cases 
of right atrial enlargement. The patient is showing features of heart failure possibly as a 
consequence of dysfunction caused by the overload. Signs of heart failure in this patient: • Bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities (systemic congestion) • Worsening dyspnea due to increased PCWP causing pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary 
edema (pulmonary congestion) The features of P pulmonale include: • The amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1 820 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG? 806 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right 
ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Diagnostic criteria for RVH: • Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1). • Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1). • Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) 
and inferior leads (II, III, aVF) • Right axis deviation of +110° or more. For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used. It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S 
wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm). 821 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain 
that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken 
immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.explanation:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block 
(LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features: • Wide QRS complex- QRS 120 ms • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead 
V6. • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) MI can have the following ECG changes: • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury • T wave depression • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop • New left bundle branch block (LBBB) 822 
Sold by @itachibot The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in 
V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6) The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; 
R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6) 823 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 50-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain 
radiating to the jaw. The patient initially felt some uneasiness while eating lunch after which 
he experienced pain. His ECG is as shown. Interpret his ECG.
questions.explanation:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial 
infarction. Features of MI on ECG: • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury • T wave inversions • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop • New left bundle branch block (LBBB) Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves. Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that 
he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis? 808 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal 
myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall 
infarction. 824 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 52-year-old diabetic man presents with retrosternal chest pain and profuse sweating and 
lightheadedness. Based on the ECG findings, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The ECG shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1-V6. This is suggestive of extensive anterior 
wall MI.

questions.question: Question 16: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
questions.explanation:
The ECG is suggestive of lateral wall MI and possible posterior wall MI. ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6. Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression 
in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI). This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral 
wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).

questions.question:
Question 17: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on 
the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this 
ECG? 810 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI. The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include, • Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in 
this way • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3 • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2 • Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following ECG findings are unlikely to be present in a patient with 
hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation:
Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia. 825 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient was brought to the ER with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting, increased 
frequency of urination, and constipation for the past 5 days. He also complained of lethargy 
and muscle pain. He is a known case of SCC of the lung. What is likely to be seen in the ECG 
of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related 
peptides. It is mostly associated with squamous-cell lung cancer (SCC). ECG is likely to 
show a decreased QT interval. Hypocalcemia shows increased QT interval.

questions.question:
Question 20: ECG of a patient revealed a QT interval of 0.55s. Which of the following will not be a 
differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
QT interval of 0.55s suggests QT prolongation. It is not seen in digitalis toxicity. Rather, a QT 
shortening with characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex, called a digitalis effect, is 
seen. The ECG changes seen in digitalis toxicity are as follows: • Prolonged PR interval • ST-segment depression • Short QT interval QT interval represents the time taken for the ventricles to depolarize and repolarize. It is 
prolonged in the following: • Hypocalcemia • Hypokalemia • Congenital long QT syndromes such as Romano-Ward syndrome • Hypothermia • Drugs: Class IA and Class III antiarrhythmics 826 
Sold by @itachibot • Intracranial bleeds: particularly SAH

questions.question: Question 21: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Osborn waves are seen in hypothermia. Osborn waves can also be seen in severe hypothyroidism (Option A), but even in those cases, 
hypothermia is the reason for the appearance of Osborn waves. Therefore, hypothermia is the 
better answer here. It consists of an abrupt ascent right at the J point (the junctional point between the QRS complex 
and the ST segment) and then an equally sudden plunge back to the baseline. It is also called the J 
wave. This is because systemic hypothermia prolongs repolarisation. Osborn wave can also be seen in: • Hypercalcemia • Brain injury • Subarachnoid hemorrhage • Vasospastic angina • Cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation • Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation

questions.question:
Question 22: In a patient with a left-sided massive pneumothorax, all of the following ECG changes are 
seen except:
questions.explanation:
Right axis deviation is seen in left-sided pneumothorax. The ECG changes seen in left-sided pneumothorax are as follows: 827 
Sold by @itachibot • Reduced R wave amplitude • Inversion of T wave in precordial leads • Amplitude changes in QRS complex • Right axis deviation 828 
Sold by @itachibot Supraventricular Arrhythmias
